topic.title: Creating the HPE Helion Development Platform Service Net

section.p: Many of the HPE Helion Developer Platform services require the creation of a VM service network in order to access the cloud control plane. This service network is a VLAN-encapsulated provider network which is fully routable to the MGMT network.
You should complete these steps prior to doing your HPE Helion Development Platform installation.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: These steps assume you have already allocated a VLAN for the Service Net prior to beginning these steps.

section.title: Specifying Your Service Net VLAN in the Input Model
section.p: You will need to specify your Service Net in the input model, either during the Configure Your Environment portion of the installation or you can do it post-installation using the steps below.

ol.li: Log in to your lifecycle manager.

Configure your my_cloud definition to include the service network. This is used to provide routing from management (and potentially other networks) back to the newly created service net.
Ensure that the service network is routable from the management network and that the service network is defined in ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml.
Here is an example showing the two new entries you need to make in this file: # # Management # # This is the network group that will be used to for # management traffic within the cloud. # # The interface used by this group will be presented # to Neutron as physnet1, and used by provider VLANS # # In this example this group is also used for ISCSI # traffic between VMs and the VSA block storage # - name: MANAGEMENT hostname-suffix: mgmt hostname: true
component-endpoints: - default
routes: - default - SERVICE
load-balancers: - provider: ip-cluster name: lb components: - default roles: - internal - admin
tags: - neutron.networks.vlan: provider-physical-network: physnet1
- name: SERVICE
Ensure that there is a valid definition for the service network in the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/networks.yml file.
The cidr and gateway given must match the values provided when the network was created.
Here is an example showing the format: - name: SERVICE-NET vlanid: 306 tagged-vlan: true cidr: 10.1.6.0/24 gateway-ip: 10.1.6.1 network-group: SERVICE
Ensure that this network is a member of the server-group listed in the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/server_groups.yml file.
Here is an example showing this: server-groups: - name: CLOUD server-groups: - AZ1 - AZ2 - AZ3 networks: - EXTERNAL-NET - GUEST-NET - MANAGEMENT-NET - PXE-NET - SERVICE-NET
If you made these changes prior to your first run of the configuration processor, then continue with the installation steps as documented. If you are making these changes after your initial run then continue on with the next steps.
Commit your configuration to the local git repo, as follows: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config or other commit message"
Run the configuration processor with this command: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Use the playbook below to create a deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Run the site.yml playbook below: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml
If you have used an encryption password when running the configuration processor use the command below and enter the encryption password when prompted: ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --ask-vault-pass
SSH to the lifecycle manager using admin credentials.

Configure a Neutron network that will map to an external network for the service net.
For simple configurations, a lifecycle manager playbook has been provided for this purpose.
For non-trivial network configurations, any additional routes should be added to the subnet definition using the --host-route option of the neutron subnet-create command. The --host-route option can be specified multiple times if necessary. cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts neutron-svc-net-configure.yml \ -e PROV_NET_TYPE=<provider_network_type> \ -e PROV_PHYS_NET=<physical_network_name> \ -e PROV_NET_VLAN_ID=<vlan_id> \ -e SVC_NET_CIDR=<provider_network_cidr> \ -e SVC_NET_DEST=<svc_net_destination> \ -e SVC_NET_GATEWAY="gateway_used_by_the_network" \ -e SVC_ALLOCATION_START="10.241.0.70" \ -e SVC_ALLOCATION_END="10.241.0.125"Example: Given a management network with the following attributes: MGMT Net = 192.168.245.1/24 SVC Net = 10.55.66.0/24 SVC gateway to MGMT = 10.55.66.3 SVC Net VLAN = 100 the playbook command for creating the service network would be: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts neutron-svc-net-configure.yml -e PROV_NET_TYPE=vlan -e PROV_PHYS_NET=physnet1 -e PROV_NET_VLAN_ID=100 -e SVC_NET_CIDR=10.55.66.0/24 -e SVC_NET_DEST=192.168.245.1/32 -e SVC_NET_GATEWAY=10.55.66.3 To configure a service network for flat encapsulation, modify the service network creation statement: -e PROV_NET_TYPE flat The subnet creation statement does not change.
